awd_titl_txt: Electric field-based enhancement and control of film and nucleate boiling heat transfer
awd_abstract_narration:
Electric field-based enhancement and control of film and nucleate boiling heat transfer

Boiling heat transfer influences the performance of many industrial processes like steam generation, desalination and quenching. Enhanced heat transfer improves the energy efficiency of thermal processes and reduces the operating temperatures. At high temperatures, boiling heat transfer is drastically reduced due to the formation of an insulating vapor layer between the surface and the liquid. This well-known Leidenfrost effect (film boiling) is responsible for adversely affecting the performance of industrial equipment which involves boiling. An electrical voltage applied across this vapor layer can promote liquid-surface wetting, thereby eliminating dryout and enhancing heat transfer. Similarly, an electric field can control bubbles, which also influences boiling heat transfer. The proposed research is a fundamental study on the influence of electric fields in multiple regimes of boiling heat transfer. Electrical suppression of the Leidenfrost state will be analyzed and the resulting heat transfer enhancement will be quantified. Electric-field-based control of physical phenomena associated with bubbles will be analyzed to quantify electric field-enhanced heat transfer in the nucleate boiling regime (which involves bubbles). The proposed research includes experimentation, analytical modeling and numerical simulations. Overall, the proposed research will develop a new area of study in the field of boiling heat transfer. This will also set the stage for the development of novel heat transfer technologies which impact the energy and materials processing sectors. The impact of this work is particularly evident in the area of quenching (ultrafast cooling), where electrically tunable cooling offers a new tool to control the microstructure and mechanical properties of metals.

The proposed research studies the influence of interfacial electric fields on film and nucleate boiling heat transfer, for liquids with very low (but finite) electrical conductivity (like organic solvents and deionized water). In such liquids, the applied voltage is expressed across the electrically insulating vapor gap or bubble. This localized interfacial electric field can influence boiling-related phenomena more strongly than the volumetric electric field in electrically insulating liquids. The proposed research will directly measure the heat transfer coefficients and analyze the fundamental mechanisms underlying heat transfer enhancement. This work involves the development of a high heat flux, high temperature pool boiling test facility to measure the critical heat flux (CHF), which is the maximum heat flux that avoids dryout. The physics underlying Leidenfrost state suppression will be captured by single droplet experiments and analysis. The influence of electric fields on microfluidic phenomena like bubble growth, oscillations, and detachment will be studied by single bubble high speed visualizations and analytical modeling. Experiments will be conducted with deionized water and isopropanol/methanol as working fluids. Specific outcomes of this work include measurements of electrically enhanced heat transfer coefficients and CHF?s, and an in depth understanding of the micro/mesoscale thermal-fluid-electrical phenomena influencing boiling heat transfer. Overall, the proposed research will lead to seminal contributions in the field of boiling heat transfer. This research can potentially reshape the boiling curve by making the CHF limit irrelevant and increasing heat transfer coefficients. This work also lays the foundations for electrically tunable boiling heat transfer.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit:

This project was aimed at studying the influence of electric fields on the heat transfer associated with boiling of fluids. Boiling is an important phenomena which influences several industrial applications like steam generation, refining, metals processing etc. In particular, the focus of this project was on a study of surface dryout prevention during boiling, which occurs when liquid rests on its own vapor layer on a hot surface, thereby starving the surface of liquid contact; this phenomena is also known as the Leidenfrost state.

This project has created significant fundamental knowledge, and contributed to developing a new research area in boiling heat transfer. Most importantly, it has shown that electric fields control and enhance heat transfer significantly; this knowledge will benefit several practical applications. This research has been highly multidisciplinary in nature and has involved fluid mechanics, heat transfer, electrostatics and materials. Specific outcomes included measurements of electrically enhanced heat transfer (during boiling), analysis of various phenomena associated with electrostatic suppression of the Leidenfrost state, and an understanding of the coupled thermal-fluid-electrical phenomena influencing boiling heat transfer.

Specific findings are detailed in various archival journal articles and are summarized below:

  • 2014 paper (Langmuir): Showed that the Leidenfrost state (dryout condition) can be suppressed electrostatically for multiple liquids, even at temperatures as high as 400 ºC. Eliminating the Leidenfrost state enhanced heat transfer by > 10X.
  • 2016 paper (Appl. Phys. Lett.): Reported experimental studies on electrostatic suppression of Leidenfrost state during high temperature quenching of metals. Showed that a fundamental switch in the heat transfer mode significantly accelerates cooling. This work sets the stage for electrically tunable quenching (heat treatment) of steels, which can be used to control mechanical properties.
  • 2016 paper (Nano. Microscale Thermophys. Engg.): This was a comprehensive review article on electric field-enhanced boiling and condensation.
  • 2017 paper (Appl. Phys. Lett.): Studied the role of AC electric fields on electrostatic suppression of the Leidenfrost state. Discovered that the extent of suppression is reduced with increasing AC frequency.
  • 2017 paper (Phys. Rev. Fluids): Analyzed the instability underlying electrostatic suppression to predict the minimum voltage required for suppression. Linear instability analysis was done to model growth of electrostatically-induced interfacial perturbations.
  • 2017 paper (Langmuir): Studied electrostatic suppression of the Leidenfrost state of one liquid resting on another liquid (hot). Discovered that the nature of suppression is markedly different from that on solid surfaces.
  • 2018 paper (Phys. Rev. E): Studied ‘acoustic signature tracking’ to obtain insights into electrostatic suppression of the Leidenfrost state. This involved measuring the acoustic signature of a liquid drop in the Leidenfrost state, before and during suppression.
  • 2019 paper (Appl. Phys. Lett.): Used an electrical technique (impedance characterization) to measure the extent of solid-liquid contact during electrostatic suppression of the Leidenfrost state.
  • 2019 paper (Intl. J. Heat Mass Trans.): Developed a physics-based model to predict the increase in heat transfer associated with electrostatic suppression of the Leidenfrost state. This model was validated by experiments.
  • 2020 paper (Phys. Fluids): Studied the phenomena of burst of a vapor bubble in a liquid drop in the Leidenfrost state. This included developing a numerical model to predict burst; this model was validated with experiments.

Broader impacts:

This research has enabled future development of technologies related to electrically tunable boiling heat transfer with applications in energy production, electronics cooling and materials processing. This work has directly supported the PhD dissertations of two students at UT Austin in addition to providing research opportunities to 4 undergraduate students. Research conducted during this project is being used in a new graduate course being developed by the PI.


Last Modified: 11/06/2022
Modified by: Vaibhav Bahadur

Images (1 of )
  • Left image: A liquid drop resting on a vapor cushion resulting from boiling on a hot surface. This is known as Leidenfrost state, wherein the surface dries out (starved of liquid). Right image: Applying an electric field causes the liquid to electrowet surface, eliminating surface dryout.
    Bahadur group@UT
    Copyrighted
    Vaibhav Bahadur
    Electrical suppression of dryout of a hot surface (Leidenfrost state)
  • Quenching (cooling) of metals from high temperatures can be accelerated by using electric fields to eliminate dryout and promote liquid-metal contact. Left: Metal sphere cooling slowly due to insulating vapor gap Right: Fast cooling due to electrical suppression of surface dryout.
    Bahadur group@UT
    Copyrighted
    Vaibhav Bahadur
    Electrically enhanced quenching of metals
  • Plots show that heat transfer associated with boiling can be controlled and enhanced by electric fields (via control of surface dryout). The classical boiling curve can be tuned using electric fields. This enables options for digital control of boiling.
    Bahadur group@UT
    Copyrighted
    Vaibhav Bahadur
    Electrically tunable boiling heat transfer
  • Surface dryout can be monitored acoustically. Dryout has a very low acoustic signature since there is no fluid-solid contact. Dryout suppression can be picked up by tracking the acoustic signature associated with liquid-solid contact and splashing.
    Bahadur group@UT
    Copyrighted
    Vaibhav Bahadur
    Acoustic detection of dryout suppression
  • Sequence of images shows electrical dryout suppression of a liquid drop on the surface of another hot liquid. The drop is essentially sucked into the hot pool upon the application of an electric field.
    Bahadur group@UT
    Copyrighted
    Vaibhav Bahadur
    Dryout suppression on liquid surfaces
  • Electrical suppression of the Leidenfrost state (dryout prevention) depends on the frequency of the electrical waveform used. Images show that DC voltages results in maximum suppression, with the extent of suppression reducing as the frequency of AC waveform increases.
    Bahadur group@UT
    Copyrighted
    Vaibhav Bahadur
    AC frequency dependent dryout suppression
